title: Protecting Our Information
body:
Information is valuable but our growing reliance on technology increases the risk of digital vulnerabilities that could be exploited by others.

At Sonron Engineering, we need your help to protect our confidential information from falling into the hands of malicious parties, such as:

title: Anytime, Anywhere
body:
The methods and ways that information threats occur are numerous.

For instance, malicious software, also called malware, is a common digital attack that can be incredibly costly and disruptive for a business.

title: Social Engineering
body:
Social engineering is a common method of exploiting organizational vulnerabilities. It relies on human nature instead of technology to breach our security.

  • Manipulates human emotions or personal knowledge to gain trust.
  • Conducted through personalized communication (i.e. email, phone, or in person).
  • Can occur anywhere and anytime.

Phishing is a type of social engineering that works through falsified communications. Criminals will send plausible emails or text messages that masquerade as a trusted contact to manipulate users into accessing a malicious link or entering sensitive personal information.

This can result in the compromise of user data, like login credentials or credit card numbers, and damage a business through unauthorized purchases, stolen funds, or identity theft.

Click on the numbered circles to see what you should consider before responding to an email!

title: Be Aware, Be Vigilant
body:
As a Sonron employee, you will often have to use swipe cards or ID passes to gain access to our business offices or client facility buildings.

As such, you may encounter people who ask for help in gaining access to secure areas. They might mention that they have forgotten their pass, one way or another.

While, it may be an honest excuse. It could also be a social engineering technique, called "tailgating" or "piggybacking".

Malicious actors will exploit our natural instinct to assist others. Even if you’re acting in good faith, you could be assisting in a security breach. If you find yourself in this situation, try to:

title: Practice Scenario
body:
Check your understanding of security threats by completing the following practice scenario!

As a Sonron employee, you have been tasked with handling a project at a client location. You are issued a temporary security pass that gives you access to certain secure areas of their facility grounds.

One day as you are entering a refinery control center, an individual covered from head to toe in personal protective equipment, typical to engineering facility sites, approaches you.

They politely say, “Hi, sorry for holding you up! I was wondering if you wouldn’t mind letting me in. I forgot my pass and I have to get some urgent work done today.”

title: Reporting Procedure
body:
Our safety protocols require you to contact the appropriate people in the case of a suspected security incident.

A security incident is any event that may compromise the confidentiality, privacy, integrity, or availability of our information and systems.

title: Course Complete
body:
Congratulations! You have completed the Information Security Compliance Training experience.

You are now able to:
